items.title: Blank Popup Using S3
items.body:
## Describe Issue
I am using django-tinymce with static files on aws s3. I can edit, format and save text, but I got blank popup window when create table, or create hyperlink (anything with popup window). Then I saw on console log this message.
`Uncaught DOMException: Permission denied to access property "tinymce" on cross-origin object`

## Codes
### my requirements
```
 ...
 Django==2.0.7
 django-tinymce==2.8.0
 django-storages==1.9.1
```

### my cors setting.
```
<CORSConfiguration xmlns="http://s3.amazonaws.com/doc/2006-03-01/">
<CORSRule>
    <AllowedOrigin>*</AllowedOrigin>
    <AllowedMethod>GET</AllowedMethod>
    <AllowedMethod>HEAD</AllowedMethod>
    <AllowedMethod>POST</AllowedMethod>
    <AllowedMethod>PUT</AllowedMethod>
    <AllowedMethod>DELETE</AllowedMethod>
    <AllowedHeader>*</AllowedHeader>
</CORSRule>
</CORSConfiguration>
```

### settings.py
```
INSTALLED_APPS = [
   ...
    'django.contrib.staticfiles',
    'tinymce',
    'storages',

]

...

STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'static')
STATIC_URL = f'https://{bucket_name}.s3.amazonaws.com/static/'

TINYMCE_JS_URL = os.path.join(STATIC_URL, "tiny_mce/tiny_mce.js")
TINYMCE_JS_ROOT = os.path.join(STATIC_URL, "tiny_mce")
TINYMCE_DEFAULT_CONFIG = {
    'plugins': "table,xhtmlxtras,paste,searchreplace,preview,advlist,wordcount",
    'theme': "advanced",
    'cleanup_on_startup': True,
    'custom_undo_redo_levels': 10,
    'relative_urls': False,
    'width': '100%',
    'height': 300,

    'theme_advanced_toolbar_location': "top",
    'theme_advanced_toolbar_align': "left",
    'theme_advanced_statusbar_location': "bottom",
    'theme_advanced_resizing': True,

    'theme_advanced_buttons1': "bold,italic,underline,strikethrough,|,justifyleft,justifycenter,justifyright,justifyfull,styleselect,formatselect,fontselect,fontsizeselect",
    'theme_advanced_buttons2': "cut,copy,paste,pastetext,pasteword,|,search,replace,|,bullist,numlist,|,outdent,indent,blockquote,|,undo,redo,|,link,unlink,anchor,image,cleanup,help,code,|,insertdate,inserttime,preview,|,forecolor,backcolor",
    'theme_advanced_buttons3': "tablecontrols,|,hr,removeformat,visualaid,|,sub,sup,|,cite,abbr",
    'remove_linebreaks' : True,
}
```

### urls.py
```
from django.conf.urls.static import static

...

urlpatterns = urlpatterns \
+ static(settings.MEDIA_URL,
        document_root=settings.MEDIA_ROOT) \
+ static(settings.STATIC_URL,
        document_root=settings.STATIC_ROOT)
```
## What I expected to happen
I can create table and hyperlink with tinymce module on an aws s3 bucket. 

I already googling for solutions but still same.
Could you help me with this ?
Thank you.

items.title: Widget in Admin breaks Select2 JS
items.body:
When adding the TinyMCE widget to the Admin, it's breaking the fields that are set under the ModelAdmin's autocomplete_fields setting. The console is giving the following error message:

`TypeError: $element.select2 is not a function` coming from autocomplete.js

I've tested with different ways of adding TinyMCE to the Admin - formfield_overrides for widget, custom ModelForm, and the HTMLField. They all break the autocomplete_fields. It seems rendering TinyMCE on the page is somehow preventing Django's built-in Select2 JS from loading.

EDIT: Actually, it seems that TinyMCE is breaking **all** Select2 JS, even if I'm using the django-select2 package for it. My other Select2Widget and Select2MultipleWidget fields all break as soon as I enable the TinyMCE widget. This gives the following error:

`TypeError: $ is undefined` from django_select2.js

items.title: Maybe solved - [Django] Internal Server Error: /tinymce/compressor/
items.body:
UnicodeDecodeError at /tinymce/compressor/
'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 3146: ordinal not in range(128)

This prevented tinymce from working properly. It was apparently fixed by making the following change to tinymce/compressor.py

from
37    try:
38        f = open(file_path)
39        try:

to
37    try:
38        f = open(file_path, encoding='utf-8')
39        try:

Django 2.1.9
Python 3.6
Ubuntu 18.04

I don't know what consequences might occur elsewhere. I'll keep my eye on it.

TinyMCE widget does not work with MultiWidget setup in Django
items.body:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.1/ref/forms/widgets/#multiwidget
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.1/ref/forms/fields/#multivaluefield

Using a MultiValueField with a MultiWidget as described in the django documentation does not work as expected.

Test:

Setup a form with a MultiValueField' as one of the fields

```
from django import forms
from tinymce.widgets import TinyMCE
from .models import SomeModel

class CustomMultiWidgetUsingTinyMCE(forms.widgets.MultiWidget):
	def __init__(self, attrs=None):
		_widgets = (
			TinyMCE,
			TinyMCE()
		)

	def decompress(self, value):
		# ...
		return 'something'

class CustomMultiValueField(forms.MultiValueField):
	widget = CustomMultiWidgetUsingTinyMCE
	
	def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
		fields = (
            forms.CharField(),
            forms.CharField()
        )

	def compress(self, values):
		# ...
		return 'something'

class ComplexForm
	multiValueField = CustomMultiValueField()
```

Setting up the form in a similar way as the code above you will notice that the multiValueField will fail to render as TinyMCE widgets for the relevant fields.

I've tested this against other Django widgets and the MultiWidget/Value setup works well for other types of Widgets (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.1/ref/forms/widgets/) it's only when using the TinyMCE widget that it fails.

One thing I've noticed is that the TinyMCE render method is not called when using the MultiWidget/Value setup but it renders correctly for all the other use cases that I've tested.

This is a bit of an obscure use-case, but the essence is that the TinyMCE widget-like class doesn't work correctly as a widget should under all test/use cases.

items.title: Attrs set on the TinyMCE form widget are not added used in build_attrs
items.body:
In widgets.py in TinyMCE.render, build_attrs is called, but only the attrs passed into the render function are used. It does not currently use the attrs that are passed to the widget on instantiation.

This causes the documented method of changing the rows and cols of the widget invalid.

Changing that call to build_attrs(self.attrs, attrs) should fix the issue.

Chris

items.title: TinyMCE not initialized after an inline is added
items.body: I'm on Django 1.10; one of the recent versions must have changed the DOM slightly (I'm not intimately familiar with the Django admin templates; perhaps the DOM is different from what the author of django-tinymce it would look like because of my model definitions?), and the "Add another " button now uses the following hierarchy: ``` ... Add another ... ``` As a result, the JS code in init_tinymce.js fails: `if(!ev.target.parentNode || ev.target.parentNode.className.indexOf("add-row") === -1)` this condition is never satisfied, because `ev.target.parentNode.className` is empty (since the parent is the `td` node). A simple fix is to do this instead: ``` if (!ev.target.parentNode || !ev.target.parentNode.parentNode || ev.target.parentNode.parentNode.className.indexOf("add-row") === -1) { return; } var $addRow = $(ev.target.parentNode.parentNode); ```

items.title: Required fields and browser validation
items.body:
Apparently, when a textarea having the `required` attribute is powered by TinyMCE, browser validation (Firefox tested) is preventing form submission, as the textarea itself is considered empty by the browser.
This can be workarounded by using `TinyMCE(attrs={'required': False})` as widget definition in the Django form. I've also seen some JS snippets trying to fix this.

Is this something django-tinymce should force doing?

items.title: smart_text import in compressor.py breaks support for Django 1.4.1 and prior
items.body:
#158 adds `from django.utils.encoding import smart_text` to compressor.py

I was able to upgrade my project to use Django 1.4.2, which seems to be the first version to enable smart_text to be used in place of smart_unicode (I believe in all 1.4.2+ versions it is an alias, but eventually smart_text replaces smart_unicode at some point). Anyway, I just wanted to let you know so that you can update your documentation to say that Django 1.4.2+ is required now. That, or I believe it may be possible to do a try catch on the ImportError and import smart_unicode as smart_text if smart_text isn't available.

items.title: python3 issue with spellchecker
TinyMCE options that expect JavaScript functions are not supported
items.body:
There are several TinyMCE options (`color_picker_callback`, `file_browser_callback`, `images_upload_handler`, etc.) that expect to receive a JavaScript function as their value. But because django-tinymce serializes all of the configuration options as JSON, functions cannot be passed through from Python.

For example, if I had a JavaScript function `myColorPicker` that I wanted to install as the `color_picker_callback`, I'm out of luck:

``` Python
TINYMCE_DEFAULT_CONFIG = {
  'color_picker_callback': ??? # No way to specify the JavaScript function
}
```

I've submitted a pull request https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/pull/151 that allows you to specify the _name_ of a JavaScript function in the Python configuration code. This name is resolved in the JavaScript initialization code, before calling `tinymce.init`. So, you could do something like:

``` Python
TINYMCE_DEFAULT_CONFIG = {
  'color_picker_callback': 'myColorPicker'  # name of function assumed to be defined in JS
}
```

This seems to work well for my needs.

items.title: django-tinymce future and tests
items.body:
**Fact: A number of people relies on django-tinymce for their application.**

In order to guarantee the quality and the maintenance of this project we should write tests so that we can guarantee which version of Python and Django django-tinymce is working with.

Today there are manual tests that can let us see if django-tinymce is working in the admin and in a form but we need to automate this tests and make them run on travis-ci.

The good news is that Django comes with [Selenium integration](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/topics/testing/tools/#liveservertestcase) so it should not be that hard.

Feel free to add things that you think should be tested here so that we can plan an effective roadmap of what should be tested.

**Unit tests**
- [x] [HTMLField](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/models.py#L13-L26) default widget should be [tinymce.widgets.AdminTinyMCE](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/widgets.py#L119-L120)
- [x] [get_language_config ](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/widgets.py#L123-L156)
- [x] [TinyMCE textarea widget](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/widgets.py#L33-L116)
- [ ] [URLs](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/urls.py) are well defined.
- [x] [spell_check view](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/views.py#L38-L73)
- [x] [flatpage_link_list view](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/views.py#L95-L102)
- [x] [compressor view](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/views.py#L105-L109)
- [x] [filebrowser view](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/views.py#L132-L139)
- [ ] [staticfiles and default settings](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/settings.py#L5-L22)
- [x] [compressor tinymce plugins file gathering](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/compressor.py)
- [x] [tinymce_preview templatetag](https://github.com/aljosa/django-tinymce/blob/master/tinymce/templatetags/tinymce_tags.py#L11-L13)

**Functional test**
- [ ] Tinymce loading in the admin (with and without compressor and with plugins)
- [ ] Tinymce loading in a form (with and without compressor and with plugins)

**We need you to help**

So if you are using TinyMCE and plan on keep using it file a Pull Request and add a test I will be there to help in the process.

items.title: Compressor does not work at all in Python 3
items.body: `compressor.py` adds a bunch of string literals to the `content` list and then calls `.decode` on each of them. Obviously this cannot work on Python 3 since you can't "decode" a Unicode string.

items.title: Widget not posting form data changes on non-admin page
items.body:
I think this may be the same problem as #123, but I'm not sure so I'm opening a new issue.

When I use a TinyMCE widget in the admin it works perfectly. However, when I use the widget in a form in a non-admin page, any changes the user makes are not being posted when the form is submitted.

I checked the POST data in the browser's network developer tool, and I see the original contents of the field being posted, despite the fact that I changed the contents of the TinyMCE widget on page. Prior to submitting the form, I inspected the TinyMCE widget in the browser's inspector. My changes appear in it, but they are not reflected in the textarea form element. I'm not sure when my changes are supposed to be copied into the textarea, but that seems to not be happening.

Any ideas?

items.body: Good evening! Cannot you add support of STATICFILES_DIRS, when we use it instead of STATIC_ROOT in new versions of Django?

items.title: Uncaught TypeError: $ is not a function
items.body:
Just added django-tinymce to my Django installation. Everything works fine, the JavaScript static files load, the markup for the tinymce is added etc…

However, I'm getting the following JavaScript error in line 10 of django_tinymce.js:

```
Uncaught TypeError: $ is not a function
```

Which seems to be caused by the changes in 6fa348f663af. If I replace the last line

``` javascript
}( function (django) { return django && django.jQuery || jQuery }()));
```

with

``` javascript
}( django && django.jQuery || jQuery ));
```

it works just fine. Didn't really check too much, but I think the main cause is the django argument of the nested function, which overrides the global django variable. Because there never actually is any argument passed in, the first check is always false and it ignores `django.jQuery` in the admin.

I guess an alternative solution would be passing the function the global django variable as an argument, but I'm not quite sure what the purpose of the extra nested function was anyways?

items.title: tinymce4 content.min.css doesn't seem to load
items.body:
I recently pulled the changes you've made to the tinymce4 branch.  Since the changes, it seems like the content.min.css doesn't load initially.  I'm searching for the source cause and working to make sure it's not just my project.  I think things were still working back on cd658228357.  

If I look at the linked css in Firebug, it says 

```
<link href="http://example.com/static/tinymce/skins/lightgray/content.min.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css">
Reload the web page to get the source for: http://example.com/static/tinymce/skins/lightgray/content.min.css
```

Deleting a few letters of the href and adding them back in causes it to load the styles.  
I'll keep you posted as I continue debugging.

items.title: Python 3 classifiers
items.body:
Does django-tinymce officially support Python 3?

If so, it would be nice to designate that on PyPI using classifiers in setup.py (see https://pypi.python.org/pypi?%3Aaction=list_classifiers)

If not, what does the path forward look like?

items.title: "ImportError: No module named defaults" in Django 1.6
items.body:
When I setup django-tinymce I get the following when trying to load a page that should have tinymce:

```
  Traceback (most recent call last):

```

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19962736/django-import-error-no-module-named-django-conf-urls-defaults

My config:

> python -c "import django; print(django.get_version())" 1.
>     1.6.2

items.title: Trying to add new inlines just shows up as text areas. Could be similar to an earlier issue
items.body:
Trying to add new inlines just shows up as text areas, no TinyMCE in sight.
Could be similar to an earlier issue, however it was closed years ago so perhaps this is a new one.

I've put a project on Github so all settings etc. can be seen: https://github.com/jonashagstedt/tinymceissue

Versions:
-  Django==1.6.2
-  django-tinymce==1.5.2
